text.p: International Business Machines Corp unveiled Thursday its Aptiva "S Series" line of "split system" personal computers designed to make computing functions easier for home users.
The split-system model allows users to place a PC keyboard and accessories in a convenient location while hiding the bulky main computer box in a separate, out-of-the-way spot.

IBM said the "S Series" will come in four basic models running either Pentium 166 or 200 megahertz chips and contain up to 3.2 gigabytes of storage capacity, the latest CD-ROM drives, modems and a variety of multimedia features.

The basic Aptiva models range in price from $2,499 to $3,099, excluding monitor, which run another $499 to $799, the prices of a 15-inch or 17-inch screen, respectively. The line is available immediately from U.S. retailers.
The new models take many of their architectural cues from the tradition of slick, modular consumer electronics.
